hotspots.hotspot:
Crust

The crust is the thinnest of Earth's layers. The crust that makes up Earth's continents is called continental crust. The crust that makes up the ocean bottom is called oceanic crust. Oceanic crust is denser than continental crust.

Mantle

Below the crust is the mantle, Earth's thickest layer. It is made of hot rock. Rocks in the upper mantle are cool and brittle, but those in the lower part of the mantle are soft. These soft rocks flow under pressure. Earth's crust floats on this layer.

Outer core

No one has seen Earth's core, but it is thought to be composed of iron and nickel. The outer core is liquid because temperatures are hot enough to melt the metals.

Inner core

Earth's densest part is its inner core. Tremendous pressure produced by the weight of the overlying rock is strong enough to keep the metals there solid.

• Plates move away from one another

multiple.question: Volcanic activity occurs along all three plate boundaries.
The Asthenosphere is part of Earth's crust.
Earth's lithosphere is composed of the crust and rigid part of the mantle.
Transform boundaries occur when two plates slide past each other.
Earth's crust is the thickest of Earth's layers.
The supercontinent, Pangaea, split into two massive continents that eventually formed the continents we know today.
The San Andreas fault is a transform boundary.
Divergent boundaries occur when two oceanic plates come together.
Earthquakes and volcanoes can be explained by plate tectonics.
